citations.narrative:
The applicant is not getting health certificates for puppies prior to being transported by an intermediate handler for sale in
commerce. On September 9, 2024, October 20, 2024, and December 4, 2024, the applicant had shipments with a total of
thirteen puppies being delivered to buyers by intermediate handlers, for which none of the puppies had an accompanying
health certificate. Health certificates are important to ensure that the puppies are free from communicable and/or
contagious diseases prior to shipment. Correct by ensuring that any dog or puppy delivered to any intermediate handler
for transportation in commerce is accompanied by a health certificate executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian.
Correct by: January 20, 2025, onward.

The facility is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for fecal sample testing. The PVC prescribes for 10% of adults
to be randomly tested on a yearly basis and 10% of total puppy litter numbers be tested yearly. On April 24, 2024, the
licensee had one adult fecal sample tested. No additional adult or puppy fecal samples were tested in 2024. The adult
kennel population is typically between 15-22 dogs, so a minimum of two fecal samples should have been performed on
adult dogs, along with 10% of the puppy population. The inspector spoke with the office of the Attending Veterinarian to
confirm these details. Routine fecal testing is a diagnostic screening tool used to evaluate the presence of intestinal
parasites in a kennel. Diagnosing intestinal parasites is important because they can be contagious between dogs and also
transferred to humans, in addition to causing diarrhea, weight loss, and stress to dogs if they are present. Each dealer
must follow the PVC as detailed by the Attending Veterinarian for the sampling and treatment of parasites in accordance
with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by: February 15, 2025.

The facility is not retaining copies of all medical records. The facility reports routine fecal testing was performed in April
2024, however, there are neither records of these tests nor the test results available for review at the time of inspection.
This testing was confirmed with the office of the Attending Veterinarian. Retaining medical records is important so that
adequate veterinary care for the dogs at the facility can be evaluated by APHIS officials. Correct by ensuring the facility
retains medical records including the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other required or
recommended tests or examinations. Correct from January 21, 2025, onward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
